item.content:encoded:
Session 1 in Ruby-Kickstart

irb

  • irb -f play!

Super Basics

  • # "This is a comment"
  • name = thing declare variable, can be changed later in the script.
  • array = [] declare an array
  • defined? variable => local variable, global variable, no
  • .object_id => numbered ID of object
  • .class.ancenstors=> hierarchical class taxonomy
  • nil non-object object

Conversions

  • to_f to float
  • to_i to integer (truncates remainder, i.e 10.9999 => 10)
  • to_s to string

Stdout

  • puts puts string in stdout (or float or number: any object really)
  • p prints the code
  • \n new line in double quotes
  • NB! \n not a new line in single quotes
  • "stringy #{code}" => adds code to string

Stdin

  • user_response = gets, gets string, gets it from stdin

Naming Convos

  • local_variable (snake case)
  • ConstantVariable (camel case)
  • @instance_variable (asperand then snake case)

How to define a method

def method_name  
Code  
Last object (will be returned)  
end

How to define a method with argument

def method_name (argument1, argument2)  
Code relating to argument1 and argument2  
Last object (will be returned)  
end

Arithmetic Has operators (you can write beautifully, without unnecessary dots), i.e. 5.+5 => 10 == 5 + 5 => 10

  • + add
  • - less
  • * multiply
  • % find remainder aka modulus

Nb! Can be used with strings

Logic

true.class => TrueClass  
false.class => FalseClass
  • .even? Is this even?
  • .odd? Is this odd?
  • == Is this equal to?
  • = Is equal to

Nil and numbers: Is this a thing?

  • nil => fale
  • 0 => false

  • 1 => true

  • && - if A && B is true => true

  • || - if A or/|| is true => true
  • !false- is true (aka negate)

If / Else

if condition is true  
then

elsif condition is true  
then

else  
then

end

or

#basic examples 

block if condition 

#other exampels:

block unless condition  
block if A && B  
block if A || B  
block unless !A || (B && C)

Session 2 in Ruby-Kickstart

Blocks

Method(argument) {|parameter| parameter * 2}

Array

index = n-1, as such: 

my_array = [A, B, C]  
my_array[0] => A  
my_array[-1] => C  
my_array[0..1] => [1, B

it also works the other way around: 

my_array[-3] => A  
my_array[-4] => nil

Iterating over arrays

.each: do something to each element

my_array = [0, 1, 2]  
my_array.each { |variable| method }

.map: do something to each element and map a new array in relation to the old array

my_array = [0, 1, 2]  
my_new_array = my_array.map { |variable| method }

.each_slice(n): do something to groups of n variables (but don't map it to a new array)

result = []  
my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.each_slice { |a, b| result << [a, b]}  
result => [[0, 1],[2, 3]]

.each_cons(n): do something to each variables and groups of n consecutive variables (but don't map it to a new array)

result = []  
my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.each_cons { |a, b| result << [a, b]}  
result => [[0, 1],[1, 2]...]

.select: create a new array for any element that passes a test and returns true 

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_new_array = my_array.select { |number| number.even?}  
my_new_array => [0, 2]

.reject: the opposite of select (if returns true does not include)

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_new_array = my_array.reject { |number| number.even?}  
my_new_array => [1, 3]

If you want to modify the old array, use bang (!) i.e. 

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.reject! { |number| number.even?}  
my_array => [1, 3]

Add elements to an array: 

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]

my_array + [4, 5]

or 

my_array << 4  
my_array << 5

my_array => [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Replace elements in an array: 

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array[1] = 'One'  
my_array = [0, 'One', 2, 3]

.delete_at: delete index

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.delete at 1  
my_array = [0, 2, 3]

.delete: delete objects that are the same as variable

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.delete 2  
my_array => [0, 1, 3]

.delete: delete objects that are the same as variable

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.delete 2  
my_array => [0, 1, 3]

.insert(n): insert at a n

my_array = [0, 1, 2, 3]  
my_array.insert(1), "fluff"  
my_array => [0, 1, fluff, 3]

.sort

my_array = [2, 4, 3, 1]  
my_array.sort!  
my_array =  [1, 2, 3, 4]

Classes

Classes are objects of the class class.

Classes are containers for groups of methods associated with each class e.g. String, Hash, Array.

NB! .new is a method that belongs to class

Print this:

Class.instance_method 'method' => Class#method

What object am in?

'self'

e.g.

'Class.new => Class#new`

Add method to class

e.g.
%

Instance variables

Basics: 

true.class => TrueClass  
false.class => FalseClass

Cool way to use this for storing data in a more pleasing way:

.even? *Notice the name of the methods here (ruby knows that method=(blue) is the same as method = blue).

Now, you can do this with a class method called attr_accessor:

class Horse  
 attr_accessor 'color'
end

fluffy = Horse.new  
fluffy.color = "Brown"  
fluffy.color => Brown

You can also set default values to instance variables

class Horse  
 def initalize(color, age)
     @color = nil 
     @age = 0  
 end

 attr_accessor 'color'
end

fluffy = Horse.new 'Brown, 3'

fluffy.color => Brown  
fluffy.age => 3

item.dc:creator: Christopher Kummelstedt
item.content:encoded:
Some background

  • Matz wrote Ruby in 1995.
  • Paradigms are the basic choices you make when designing a source code. For ruby they are procedural, object oriented and functional.
  • OO (object oriented) = "paradigm based on the concept of "objects", which may contain data, in the form of fields, often known as attributes; and code, in the form of procedures, often known as methods."
  • Why Ruby? It hot! Ruby and Rails are firmly entrenched in the job market (and already was by 2011).
  • "Whoever holds they keys to programming ends up building the reality in which everyone will live"

Helpful hints

This post collects everything that I needed to look up during week 2 of Makers Academy.

1.2 Float that integer

If you want a value in float form (i.e. not an integer) you can manipulate it with a float:

  • X == 2
  • X / 1.0
  • return X

Will return 1.0 (rather than 1)

1.3 Equal sign sillyness

In logical statements you need to use == - not just =.

1.5 Subing parts of a string

  • MyArray = MyString.split(" ")

Turning a string into an array by splitting it at " " (spaces)

  • MyArray.join(" ")

Turning an array into string by adding " " (spaces) between elements.

The correct answer uses string.gsub('old', 'new'). As I forgot about this useful tool I did this strange thing - first I had some problems changing the array elements to happy/Happy:

happyString.each do |ss|  
if ss == "sad"  
ss = "Happy"  
elsif ss == "Sad"  
ss = "Happy"  
end

But then I realised that I was using the wrong method, .collect! does the trick though:

def add_more_ruby(string)

    happyString = string.split(" ")

    happyString.collect! { |element| (element == "sad") ? "happy" : element}
    happyString.collect! { |element| (element == "Sad") ? "Happy" : element}

    doneString = happyString.join(" ")

    puts doneString


end

add_more_ruby("The clowns were sad.")

.collect! works like this:

array.collect! {|variable| block } -> a new array that has been processed through block. In the above the block is (element == "sad") ? "happy" : element}. i.e. it asks if the array element is equal to sad, and if it is, it is changed to happy.

At this point i started to cry real crocodile tears because even after all this odyssey the happy string did not do something magical and clever with period. Hence, back to .gsub:

string.gsub("sad", "happy").gsub("Sad", "Happy")

Rake loved it.

1.6 More string glory

My solution (with sage advice from Omar): 

def odds_and_evens(string, return_odds)  
    result = []
    if return_odds
        string.split("").each_with_index { |v, i| result << v if i.odd?}
    else
        string.split("").each_with_index { |v, i| result << v if i.even?}
    end

    result.join("") 
end

i.e.

  1. Define function
  2. Create empty array (called results)
  3. If return odd is true we will split the string into an array, then we will do something nice to each element and add an index
  4. We add the value (v) to the empty array called results if index (i) is even
  5. Then we finish by joining the array, as this is the last thing in the method, this is what it will return.

Makers Academy's solution is much shorter:

def odds_and_evens(string, return_odds)  
  to_return = ""
  string.size.times do |index|
    next if return_odds && index.even?
    next if !return_odds && index.odd?
    to_return << string[index]
  end
  to_return
end
  1. Define function
  2. Create an empty string
  3. (HAWT!) string.size.times checks how many characters it has and then performs something cool that amount of times
  4. Do |index|

1.7 Pesky nills in my string

Again, I thought this was pretty cool:

def pirates_say_arrrrrrrrr(string)  
    piratespeak = ""

    string.split("").each_with_index {|v, i| piratespeak << string[i+1] if v == "r" || v == "R"}            

    return piratespeak
end

Rake did not agree with me. The problem: when you feed it a string where r is at the end, it tries to include nil in the string - giving me this rake error: " no implicit conversion of nil into String".

How then to fix it? Maybe we could do something adding another precondition that i+1 must be smaller than string size?

def pirates_say_arrrrrrrrr(string)  
    piratespeak = ""

    string.split("").each_with_index {|v, i| piratespeak << string[i+1] if  i+1 < string.size && v == "r" || v == "R" }         

    return piratespeak
end

Yes! it worked. But! its not as cool as:

def pirates_say_arrrrrrrrr(string)  
  to_return = ""
  add_next = false
  string.size.times do |index|
    current_char = string[index,1] # the second param here tells it to get a str of length 1.

    to_return << current_char if add_next
    add_next = (current_char == "r" || current_char == "R")
  end
  to_return
end

Here, the makers masters do the following awesomness:

  1. Define the function
  2. Create a new empty string
  3. Define the add_next variable and set it to false
  4. Create a iterator dealing with index that will run for the length of the string
    4a. Define current character as a string, one in length
    4b. Add the current character to the empty string to be returned after loop IF add next is true
    4c. Then! The geniusness comes into our lives, and boy, what genius it is. As this is a loop they now set check if the current character is r or R. If it is the next time the loop is run and we are back on step 4b, it will add it if the last character was r.
  5. Then they just return the now filled string.

Voila! What glory!

However, I am not sure that is better than mine? Turns out it is: runs 0.00002 seconds faster. Bet it is because I check to make sure i + 1 is not longer than the full string each time a character is checked.

2.1 Picking the essence out of strings

Hmm! This looks fun,

  1. Create a new string thats empty, and get user input
  2. Split that user input, could use .split(" ") but that feels like cheating.
  3. Do some magic to the string
  4. Feed the magic into the empty string
  5. Return it through stdout

So, now I need to:

  1. Find a way that is not cheating and
  2. Review how you ask for a chomp.
  3. I also want to learn how you explicitly feed stuff to stout (or somewhere else for that matter).

Check if you have git

$ git --version Check version

Configure git

git config --global user.name "your name" Configure username

git config --global user.email "your email" Configure email

git config --global core.autocrlf input Configure ??

git config --global core.safecrlf true Configure ??

Setting up a git repository

mkdir gitDir Create a new directory

cd gitDirChange into it

echo "Git is Awesome" > gitText Create a file

git init Changes current directory to git repo

Git repo - creates a hidden directory that tracks changes to files in the directory.

NB! You should run git init inside the directory where the files for the project you're placing under version control are.

If you do it somewhere else you can use (rm -rf .git = remove recursively, without prompting) to remove it.

git add gitText Adds file to staging area

git rm gitText Removes a file from staging area

git commit -m "First commit" Commit all files in staging area

Example of success:

$ git commit -m "First commit" [master (root-commit) a1833e4] First commit 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)
create mode 100644 gitText

git status Gives overview of what happened since last time

git log shows a logg

git checkout a1833e4ef4a1b change back to commit with hash

git checkout master go back to current master

Connecting computer with Github repo

Add a SSH key: https://help.github.com/articles/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent/

Create repo using interface

git remote -v Check if you have any remotes (connections between a local repo and a github repo)

git remote add origin NEWREPOURL Add remote

Git push -u origin master Push master to origin and make it the default action of git push (-u)

git remote rm origin Removing a remote

item.content:encoded:
This is a cheatsheet for basic command line stuff learned in week one of Makers Academy's pre-course.

Terminal terminology

|
Pipe/Redirect stream
stdin
Standard stream in
stdout
Standard stream out
stderr
Standard error

General Terminal commands

ls Lists directory content

ls –l –A Using two switches (L for long format and A for all files hidden files are part of it)

cd ~/… Changes folder

whoami Identifies user

wc Counts lines, words and characters

date Prints date

pwd Print working directory (shows path to current folder)

touch NAME Create a new file with NAME

mkdir NAME Create a new folder with NAME

rmdir NAME Delete a folder with NAME

rm NAME delete a file with NAME use with caution

rm –r DIRECTORY -r (recursively) remove DIRECTORY

head -n 20 file top 20 rows

rm –i -i (interactively), i.e. it will ask for each file

rm –f -f (forced) even write protected files will burn use with caution

cp OLD NEW create copy OLD file as NEW file

mv NAME ../ move file NAME to folder

cat concatenate i.e. combine

/private/var/log/system.log what happened?

man ls brings up the manual for ls

Combining terminal commands

find . -name "*.txt" –print

find all files, starting with the current directory, with any name that ends in .txt and print it to the screen

grep WORD *txt

Search all *txt files and print all that contain WORD

|

Redirect stream

find . -name "*.txt" –print | grep WORD

Find all files, starting with the current directory, with any name that ends that .txt and redirect this stream to grep, grep should in turn display any pwd/file that contains word

find . -name "*.txt" –print > list.txt

Find all files, starting with the current directory, with any name that ends that .txt and create a new file containing this stream, called list.txt

find ~ -name "*.txt" -print | grep README | wc –l

Find all files, starting with the current directory, with any name that ends that .txt, then check which of those contain the word README, then display how many lines (giving us how many files)

Permissions

Types: Read, Write, Execute Class: User, Group, Others

ls –l

You can view this using long format

This presents the info on permission in the following way

USER (RWX) – GROUP (RWX) – OTHERS (RWX)

Changing permissions:

  • chmod u+w readme.txt gives reading permissions to users
  • whoami gives user

Stuff to do with interpreters, paths, env and processes

Which ruby Gives path to ruby interpreter

#! Shebang; tells computer what interpreter to use

#!/usr/bin/env ruby Loads the right interpreter for ruby

echo $HOME Gives my home directory

echo $PATH Gives a colon separated list of places the computer will look for programs.

*NB! All programs that don’t require a shebang, or alternative with similar function, live in a folder specified by path *

Env Show all key-value pairs in environment

export KEY=Value Set new pair in current terminal session

echo $KEY Echo’s value

export PATH=$PATH:/Users/fluff Add another path directory

echo "export SEASON=winter" >> ~/.bash_profile if you want to keep KV pair in your profile (keep permanently)

NB! >> means append.

ps processes currently doing something in terminal

ps x all processes (in all windows)

ps x | grep BASH all processes (in all windows) involving BASH

ps x | grep BASH | wc -l makes a list of all processes (in all windows) involving BASH and then counts how many lines are on that list (i.e. how many such processes there are)

Basic VIM

vi myFile create file i start inputting before cursor o open a new line after the current one dd delete current line and dozens of others

how to edit in VIM

  1. i (input)
  2. insert stuff
  3. press esc
  4. :w (write)
  5. :q (quit)
  6. :q! (quit without saving)

item.dc:creator: Christopher Kummelstedt
item.content:encoded:
Hello World, and welcome to a blog clearly lacking any gravitas!

This gravitas thing is an allusion to "The Culture Novels" by Ian M. Banks, a modern god of sci-fi. What makes his books so delicious is that he has a stellar command of basic assumptions. He really gets culture: gets our OS, and can play with it, substituting our basic components for alien ones. If I were to describe the magnificent milieus of his imagination with one word it would be "coherence".

Why introduce myself with this? Because what we find beautiful is a very good reflection our own lens on reality. I, like most people, am drawn to the coherent, with a special penchant for the lasting/just. I just love this quote by an Irish Poet called Donaugh: "Sustainability is the heart of things that make them beautiful". Yes it is Mr. Poet! Yes it is. In a world that is always changing, it is the momentarily lasting that is most worthy of note. This is the heart of justice.

In my spare time I do this:

I watch things, I code and I build strange art with friends.

*In my work I do this:2*

Mostly emails: I work with accelerators in Uganda, Botswana and Namibia, as an operations manager for a Swedish NGO. But what I really want to do is to create a social venture together with friends. It will probably entail some of these idea fragments:

  • Making it easier to form collectives
  • Making it easier to overcome the 'tragedy of the commons'
  • Making it easier to achieve consensus
  • Making "corrupted" value chains obsolete
